</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Interest and Other Income.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">Interest and miscellaneous income was
$26.6&nbsp;million in 2002, $28.0&nbsp;million in 2001 and
$43.0&nbsp;million in 2000. Interest and other income decreased
from 2001 to 2002 primarily due to an overall decrease in
average yields on our marketable securities despite higher cash
balances available for investment. Interest and other income
decreased from 2000 to 2001, due to lower interest income from
our marketable securities due to lower average cash balances and
yields.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Interest and Other Expenses.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">Interest and other expense increased
to $25.1&nbsp;million in 2002 from $24.7&nbsp;million in 2001
and from $18.2&nbsp;million in 2000. Interest and other expense
during 2002 increased $12.7&nbsp;million due to the recognition
of a full twelve months of interest and expense on the
5.25%&nbsp;convertible subordinated notes due 2006 issued in
August 2001. This was offset by a $7.3&nbsp;million reduction in
interest and expense due to the partial repurchase of
$140.0&nbsp;million and $387.0&nbsp;million face value of
zero-coupon convertible debt issued in 1998 during 2002 and
2001, respectively. Additionally, we entered into an interest
rate swap in July 2002 related to the 5.25%&nbsp;convertible
subordinated notes resulting in interest and expense savings
during 2002 of $4.2&nbsp;million over the stated rate. In
addition, we recorded $0.8&nbsp;million of capitalized interest
in 2002 related to the construction of the Plano, Texas office
facility. Interest and other expense increased during 2001 due
to the issuance in August 2001 of our 5.25%&nbsp;convertible
subordinated notes due 2006.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Gain on Sale of Assets and Product Line.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">We recognized a $6.7&nbsp;million and
$2.6&nbsp;million gain on the sale of the PGP Gauntlet product
line in February 2002, and the PGP Desktop/ Encryption assets
and technology in July 2002, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Gain on Investments, Net.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In 2002, we recognized a
$4.6&nbsp;million gain on the sale of equity and debt
securities. In 2001, we recognized a $10.2&nbsp;million gain on
the sale of equity and debt securities. In 2000, we recognized a
net gain of $28.7&nbsp;million on the sale of our venture and
strategic investments and a gain of $11.9&nbsp;million on the
sale of shares of Networks Associates Company Limited (Japan).
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">44
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Impairment of Strategic and Other Investments.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">For the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2002 and 2001, we recorded impairment charges of
$0.2&nbsp;million and $20.6&nbsp;million, respectively, related
to an other than temporary decline in the value of our venture
and strategic investments.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Provision for (benefit from) Income Taxes.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">The provision for (benefit from)
income taxes was $(0.3)&nbsp;million, $66.0&nbsp;million and
$40.9&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Tax
expense was 0% and 45% of earnings before income taxes and
minority interest for 2002 and 2001, respectively. Tax expense
for 2000 was 58% respectively, of loss before provision for
income taxes, minority interest and extraordinary item. The
decrease in the effective tax rate from 2001 to 2002 was
primarily attributable to the utilization of tax attributes
along with more income being derived in lower tax jurisdictions.
Each year, our tax expense is mainly influenced by the mix of
income between geographic jurisdictions, including taxable
income in certain foreign countries.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The valuation allowance for our deferred tax
assets decreased from 2001 to 2002. The decrease was primarily
due to the release of the valuation allowance associated with
deferred tax assets related to McAfee.com. The valuation
allowance for our deferred tax assets increased from 2000 to
2001. The increase was due to uncertainty of our ability to
utilize some of our deferred tax assets, primarily foreign tax
credits.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Extraordinary Gain.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In 2002 and 2001, we redeemed portions
of our zero coupon convertible subordinated debentures due 2018
for approximately $66.2&nbsp;million and $173.7&nbsp;million,
respectively. The aggregate accreted value of the debentures
were $67.3 and $179.7&nbsp;million, respectively, which resulted
in an extraordinary gain of $26,000 and $1.7&nbsp;million, net
of $17,000 and $1.2&nbsp;million in taxes, in 2002 and 2001,
respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Stock-Based Compensation</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We recognized stock-based compensation expense of
$22.4&nbsp;million, $24.9&nbsp;million and $10.1&nbsp;million in
2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively. Stock-based compensation
charges relate primarily to the exchange of McAfee.com options
in connection with our acquisition of the publicly traded
minority interest in McAfee.com, non-recurring stock
compensation charges primarily related to executive compensation
and the repricing of employee stock options. We expect
significant future stock-based compensation charges related to
the exchange of McAfee.com options and repriced employee stock
options.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As more fully described in note&nbsp;21 to our
consolidated financial statements, our stock-based compensation
charges are made up of the following for the years presented (in
thousands):
</FONT>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Exchange of McAfee.com
Options.</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> On September&nbsp;13, 2002,
we acquired the minority interest in McAfee.com. In exchange for
each McAfee.com option, holders received options for 0.675 of a
share of our common stock plus $8.00 in cash, which will be paid
to the option holder only upon exercise of the option and
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">45
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">without interest. McAfee.com options to purchase
4.1&nbsp;million shares were converted into options to purchase
2.8&nbsp;million shares of our common stock. Because McAfee.com
was our consolidated subsidiary and these options were repriced
in conjunction with the acquisition of the minority interest,
these options were accounted for under the variable method of
accounting which requires that a compensation charge be
remeasured at the end of every reporting period using fair
market value.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2002, we recorded a charge of
approximately $16.1&nbsp;million related to exchanged options
subject to variable accounting. Our stock-based compensation
charge related to exchanged options subject to variable
accounting was based on our closing share price of $16.09 on
December&nbsp;31, 2002. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had
outstanding exchanged options to acquire approximately
1.2&nbsp;million of our shares subject to this variable
accounting.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Former Executives.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">Stock-based compensation charges
related to former executives include:
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Effective January 2001, William Larson, our
former chief executive officer, Prabhat Goyal, our former chief
financial officer, and Peter Watkins, our former president and
chief operating officer, became special advisors. Options held
by Mr.&nbsp;Larson, Mr.&nbsp;Goyal and Mr.&nbsp;Watkins
continued to vest during 2001 while they each served during
their one-year terms as special advisors. As a result, we
recorded a one-time stock compensation charge of approximately
$603,000 during 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In October 2002, we terminated the employment of
four former McAfee.com executives. These executives held
McAfee.com options, which were exchanged for options to acquire
our common stock. These options are subject to variable
accounting as discussed above. Upon the executives&#146;
termination, the options held by these individuals were modified
in accordance with existing change in control agreements and
became fully vested. As a result, we recorded a stock
compensation charge of $9.9&nbsp;million during 2002. We will
continue to value these options until the earlier of the date of
exercise, forfeiture or cancellation without replacement.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 2001, we terminated the employment of
three high-ranking employees. Upon termination, the options held
by these employees were modified. As a result, we recorded a
one-time stock compensation charge of $2.1&nbsp;million during
2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">New and Existing Executives.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;3, 2001, we entered
into an employment agreement with George Samenuk to become our
chief executive officer. In accordance with the terms of the
agreement, we issued 400,000&nbsp;shares of restricted stock to
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk. The price of the underlying shares is
$0.01&nbsp;per share. During 2002 and 2001, we recorded
approximately $1.1&nbsp;million and $0.8&nbsp;million,
respectively, related to stock compensation associated with
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s 2001 restricted stock grant based on the
related vesting schedule.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;3, 2001, we entered into an
employment agreement with Stephen C. Richards to become
executive vice president and chief financial officer. In
accordance with the terms of the agreement, we issued
50,000&nbsp;shares of stock to Mr.&nbsp;Richards for
$0.01&nbsp;per share. During 2001, we recorded approximately
$0.4&nbsp;million related to stock compensation associated with
Mr.&nbsp;Richards&#146; stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;30, 2001, we entered into an
employment agreement with Arthur R. Matin to become the
president of our McAfee Security product group. In accordance
with the terms of the agreement, we issued 100,000&nbsp;shares
of restricted stock to Mr.&nbsp;Matin for $0.01&nbsp;per share.
During 2001, we recorded approximately $1.9&nbsp;million related
to stock compensation associated with Mr.&nbsp;Matin&#146;s
stock based on the related vesting schedule.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;15, 2002, our board of directors
approved a grant of 50,000&nbsp;shares of restricted stock to
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk. The price of the underlying shares is
$0.01&nbsp;per share. During 2002, we recorded approximately
$0.5&nbsp;million related to stock-based compensation associated
with Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s 2002 restricted stock grant based
on the related vesting schedule.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Extended Vesting Term of Options.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">During the three months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2002, we recorded a one-time stock-based
compensation charge of $0.2&nbsp;million as a result of the
modification of the terms of the options previously granted to
certain employees.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">46
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Shares Purchased Outside Employee Stock
Purchase Plan. </FONT></I><FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;31,
2002, we experienced a shortfall in the number of shares
available under the 1994 Employee Qualified Stock Purchase Plan
to meet the requirements of the open purchase period. Although
we reduced the number of shares plan participants could purchase
by a pro rata amount, additional shares were required to be
purchased outside of the plan in order to meet this shortfall.
As a result, we recorded a one-time stock-based compensation
charge of approximately $60,000 in 2002 to account for the
difference between the fair value of the shares purchased
outside of the plan and the price the shares were sold to plan
participants.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Repriced Options. </FONT></I><FONT size="2">On
April&nbsp;22, 1999, we offered to substantially all of our
employees, excluding executive officers, the right to cancel
certain outstanding stock options and receive new options with
an exercise price equivalent to the fair market value of our
stock at the time of grant. Options to purchase a total of
10.3&nbsp;million shares were cancelled and the same number of
new options were granted. These new options vest at the same
rate that they would have vested under previous option plans and
are subject to variable accounting. Accordingly, we have and
will continue to remeasure compensation cost for these repriced
options until these options are exercised, cancelled or
forfeited without replacement. The first valuation period began
on July&nbsp;1, 2000. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, these options
were substantially fully vested. Depending upon movements in the
market value of our common stock, this accounting treatment may
result in additional stock-based compensation charges in future
periods.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2002, 2001 and 2000, we incurred charges
(credits)&nbsp;to earnings of approximately ($6.5)&nbsp;million,
$15.6&nbsp;million and $2.0&nbsp;million related to options
subject to variable plan accounting. As of December&nbsp;31,
2002, options to purchase 1.1&nbsp;million shares of the company
were outstanding and subject to variable accounting.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We also incurred an initial stock-based
compensation charge in connection with the initial issuance of
the repriced options. Approximately $1.0&nbsp;million,
$1.8&nbsp;million and $6.7&nbsp;million was expensed during
2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Warrants to Outside Consultants.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In connection with the retention of
our chief executive officer, chief financial officer and two
executive officers for our international operations, in 2001 we
issued to a retained executive search firm warrants to acquire
approximately 250,000&nbsp;shares of our common stock. We
recognized a related $1.0&nbsp;million aggregate stock-based
compensation charge based on the aggregate estimated value of
the common stock warrants on the respective grant dates.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">PGP Restructuring.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In connection with the integration of
the PGP product group, we accelerated the vesting of 45,600
options held by the 100 employees terminated during 2001. As a
result of this modification, we recorded a stock based
compensation charge of $0.5&nbsp;million with restructuring
expense in our statement of operations. The charge was
calculated based on the intrinsic value of the modified options
on the date the acceleration was approved by our board of
directors.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Options Issued Below Fair Market Value.
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">In January 2000, we issued fully
vested options to consultants. As a result, we recorded a
stock-based compensation of approximately $1.4&nbsp;million
based on the Black-Scholes model.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Liquidity and Capital Resources</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had
$674.2&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents and
$339.5&nbsp;million in marketable securities, for a combined
total of $1,013.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by operating activities was
$195.1&nbsp;million, $146.0&nbsp;million and $7.6&nbsp;million
in 2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by operating activities in 2002
was impacted primarily from non-cash charges including
depreciation and amortization, recovery from doubtful accounts,
interest on our convertible debentures, stock-based
compensation, deferred taxes, gain (loss) on investments,
extraordinary item, minority interest, gains on sales of assets
and technology and change in the fair value of the derivatives.
Additional cash was used to fund an increase of
$61.3&nbsp;million in deferred revenue offset by a increase of
$15.8&nbsp;million in our accounts receivable, an increase in
our accounts payable and accrued liabilities of
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">47
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">$78.8&nbsp;million, a decrease in prepaid
expenses and other assets of $9.7&nbsp;million and a
$46.0&nbsp;million tax benefit from the exercise of
non-qualified stock options.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by operating activities in 2001
was impacted primarily from non-cash charges including
depreciation and amortization, recovery of doubtful accounts,
interest on our convertible debentures, stock-based
compensation, deferred taxes, gains (loss) on investments,
minority interest, gains on sales of assets and technology and
change in the fair value of the derivatives. Additional cash was
used to fund an increase of $18.1&nbsp;million in our accounts
receivable and a decrease of $144.2&nbsp;million in deferred
revenue, offset by an decrease of $4.0&nbsp;million in our
accounts payable and accrued liabilities balance, a decrease of
$35.0&nbsp;million in prepaid expenses, income taxes and other
assets and a $5.4&nbsp;million tax benefit from the exercise of
non-qualified stock options.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by operating activities in 2000
was impacted primarily from non-cash charges including
depreciation and amortization, provision for doubtful accounts,
impairment of our strategic investments, interest on our zero
coupon convertible debentures, stock-based compensation charges,
deferred taxes, net gains on investments and extraordinary item
and minority interest. Additional cash was used to fund an
increase of $22.5&nbsp;million in our accounts receivable and an
increase of $24.1&nbsp;million in prepaid expenses and other
assets offset by an increase of $93.2&nbsp;million in deferred
revenue and an increase of $0.7&nbsp;million in our accounts
payable and accrued liabilities balance.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">To the extent that the non-cash items increase or
decrease our future operating results, there will be no
corresponding impact on our cash flows. After excluding the
effects of these non-cash charges the primary changes in the
operating activities relate to changes in working capital. Our
primary source of operating cash flows is the collection of
accounts receivable from our customers and the timing of
payments to our vendors and service providers.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our accounts receivable balance as a percentage
of sales may increase due to our increased emphasis on large
accounts and expanding international sales, both of which
typically have longer payment terms. Additionally, our
receivable collection has become more dependent on the longer
payment cycle for value-added resellers, distributors and system
integrators. To address this increase in accounts receivable and
to improve cash flow, we may from time to time take actions to
encourage earlier payment of receivables or sell receivables.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our operating cash flows will be impacted in the
future based on the timing of payments to our vendors for
accounts payable. We generally pay our vendors and service
providers in accordance with the invoice terms and conditions.
The timing of cash payments in the future periods will be
impacted by the nature of accounts payable arrangements and
management&#146;s assessment of our cash inflows.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by (used in) investing
activities was ($183.6)&nbsp;million, $20.7&nbsp;million, and
$(3.7)&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001, and 2000, respectively. In
2002, net cash used in investing activities includes
$98.4&nbsp;million for the purchase of the minority interest in
McAfee.com, $59.4&nbsp;million for the purchase of property and
equipment, $19.1&nbsp;million for acquisitions net of cash
acquired, and $21.7&nbsp;million being designated as restricted
cash in connection with our interest rate swap (described below)
and amounts held at escrow related to our other acquisitions.
These cash usages were offset by the proceeds from our
marketable securities portfolio of $8.7&nbsp;million, from the
sale of Secure Computing shares and the related collar of
$5.1&nbsp;million, and sale of assets and technology of
$2.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 2001, the activity in the portfolio of our
investment in marketable securities generated net cash proceeds
of $20.7&nbsp;million. These proceeds were offset by our
purchase of shares of our Japanese subsidiary owned by minority
stockholders for $10.7&nbsp;million and by our purchases of
property and equipment and technologies totaling
$31.4&nbsp;million. In 2000, we obtained cash proceeds of
$36.8&nbsp;million and $11.9&nbsp;million from the sale of our
shares in Goto.com and the sale of less than 5% of our shares in
our Japanese subsidiary, respectively. Our disbursements related
to purchases of property and equipment, technologies and other
investments for a total of $87.5&nbsp;million were partly offset
by net cash proceeds of $37.1&nbsp;million from the activity in
our investment portfolio.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">48
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by (used in) financing
activities was $43.7&nbsp;million, $158.9&nbsp;million and
($52.6)&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001, and 2000, respectively. Net
cash provided by financing activities in 2002 amounted to
$43.7&nbsp;million, consisting of cash generated from the
issuance of common stock under our stock option plans and
employee stock purchase plan of $109.9&nbsp;million offset by
cash used in the repurchase of a portion of our zero coupon
debentures of $66.2&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net cash provided by financing activities in 2001
amounted to $158.9&nbsp;million, primarily consisting of
issuance of convertible notes for $335.1&nbsp;million, as well
as issuance of common stock under our stock option plans and
employee stock purchase plan for $51.1&nbsp;million. In
addition, as described below, we settled all outstanding put
options for a payment of approximately $53.8&nbsp;million in
February 2001. These proceeds were offset by our repurchase of
zero coupon convertible debentures for $173.7&nbsp;million. Net
cash used in financing activities was $50.0&nbsp;million in 2000
consisting primarily of the repurchase of our common stock,
which represented approximately $100.4&nbsp;million. The
repurchases of our common stock were slightly offset by proceeds
associated with the exercise of our stock options and employee
stock purchase plan including the sale of put options, for a
total of $63.9&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2002, a significant portion of our cash
inflows was generated by our operations. Because our operating
results may fluctuate significantly, as a result of decrease in
customer demand or decrease in the acceptance of our future
products, our ability to generate positive cash flow from
operations may be jeopardized.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

obligations as of December&nbsp;31 (in thousands):
</FONT>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left"><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left"><HR size="4" noshade></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<P align="left">
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">In February 2003, we redeemed substantially all
    of our outstanding zero coupon debentures. As of June&nbsp;30,
    2003, there were no outstanding zero coupon debentures. The
    repurchase value set forth above corresponds to the aggregate
    face value outstanding of all of our zero coupon debentures of
    $358.5&nbsp;million less the related unamortized discount of
    $181.2&nbsp;million on February&nbsp;13, 2003.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(2)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">Under the terms of the notes, in 2003, 2004, 2005
    and 2006, we will make interest payments of $18.1&nbsp;million
    to the note holders. Pursuant to a related interest rate swap,
    the swap counter parties are obligated to make regular payments
    to us with respect to these interest obligations based on the
    5.25% interest rate and, subject to quarterly resets, we are
    required to make regular payments to the counter parties based
    on a floating rate of LIBOR plus 1.66%.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Convertible Debt</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;13, 1998, we issued zero coupon
convertible subordinated debentures due 2018 (the
&#147;Debentures&#148;) with an aggregate face amount at
maturity of $885.5&nbsp;million and generating net proceeds to
us of approximately $337.6&nbsp;million (after deducting fees
and expenses). The initial price for the Debentures was
$391.06&nbsp;per $1,000 of principal amount at maturity. (See
note&nbsp;13 to the consolidated financial statements.) Through
a limited number of privately negotiated purchases, prior to
December&nbsp;31, 2002, we repurchased zero coupon convertible
subordinated debentures with an aggregate face amount of
approximately $527.0&nbsp;million,
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">49
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">at a total price of $239.9&nbsp;million. In
connection with these repurchases, we recognized extraordinary
gains of approximately $26,000 in 2002 and $1.7&nbsp;million in
2001, net of taxes.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In accordance with their terms, at the option of
each holder, we were required to redeem the holder&#146;s
Debentures as of February&nbsp;13, 2003 at a purchase price
equal to the initial issue price plus the accretion of the
discount on the debentures to such date, or $494.52&nbsp;per
$1,000 of principal amount at maturity. On February&nbsp;13,
2003, we paid approximately $177.1&nbsp;million in cash to
redeem approximately $358.0&nbsp;million in face amount of the
Debentures. On June&nbsp;9, 2003, we redeemed the remaining
Debentures with an aggregate face amount at maturity of
$0.5&nbsp;million for a net price of $0.2&nbsp;million. In
connection with these repurchases, we recognized a loss of
approximately $2.6&nbsp;million and $0.1&nbsp;million,
respectively, calculated as the difference between the accreted
value of the debt, net of unamortized issuance costs, and the
cost of repurchase.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;17, 2001, we issued
5.25%&nbsp;convertible subordinated notes due 2006 with an
aggregate principal amount of $345.0&nbsp;million. The issuance
generated net proceeds to us of approximately
$335.1&nbsp;million (after deducting fees and expenses). The
notes mature on August&nbsp;15, 2006, unless earlier redeemed by
us at our option or converted at the holder&#146;s option.
Interest is payable semi-annually in cash in arrears on
February&nbsp;15 and August&nbsp;15 of each year, commencing
February&nbsp;15, 2002. At the option of the holder, the notes
may be converted into our common stock at any time, unless
previously redeemed, at a conversion price of $18.07&nbsp;per
share. At any time between August&nbsp;20, 2004 and
August&nbsp;14, 2005, we may redeem all or a portion of the
notes for cash at a repurchase price of 101.3125% of the
principal amount. After August&nbsp;14, 2005, the repurchase
price is 100.0% of the principal amount. The notes are unsecured
and are subordinated to all of our existing and future Senior
Indebtedness (as defined in the related Indenture).
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Stock Repurchase Program</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In May 1999, our board of directors authorized
the repurchase of up to $100.0&nbsp;million of our common stock
in the open market. In July 2000, our board of directors
authorized the repurchase of up to an additional
$50.0&nbsp;million of common stock in the open market. Through
December&nbsp;31, 2000, we repurchased 5.0&nbsp;million shares
of our common stock bringing total cash outlay to date to
approximately $112.9&nbsp;million. The timing and size of any
future stock repurchases are subject to market conditions, stock
prices, cash position and other cash requirements. Such
repurchases are intended to cover our issuances under the
Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP), the 1997 Plan, and
issuances related to potential mergers and acquisitions.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;2, 1999, February&nbsp;16, 2000
and May&nbsp;31, 2000, we sold &#147;European style&#148; put
options for 3.0&nbsp;million shares of our common stock as part
of our stock repurchase plan. On August&nbsp;3, 2000, put
options sold on August&nbsp;2, 1999 for 1.0&nbsp;million shares
were exercised in our stock. In February 2001, we settled the
remaining put options, which resulted in the purchase of
2.0&nbsp;million shares of our stock for approximately
$53.8&nbsp;million. We do not currently expect to make any
further repurchases of our common stock under this stock
repurchase program.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Financial Risk Management</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following discussion about our risk
management activities includes &#147;forward-looking
statements&#148; that involve risks and uncertainties. Actual
results could differ materially from those projected in the
forward-looking statements.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Foreign Currency Risk</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As a global concern, we face exposure to
movements in foreign currency exchange rates. These exposures
may change over time as business practices evolve and could have
a material adverse impact on our financial results. Our primary
exposures related to non U.S.&nbsp;dollar-denominated sales and
operating expenses in Japan, Canada, Australia, Europe, Latin
America, and Asia. At the present time, we hedge only those
currency exposures associated with certain assets and
liabilities denominated in nonfunctional currencies and do not
generally hedge anticipated foreign currency cash flows. Our
hedging activity is intended to offset the impact of currency
fluctuations on certain nonfunctional currency assets and
liabilities. The success of this activity depends upon estimates
of transaction activity denominated in various currencies,
primarily the Japanese Yen,
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">50
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Canadian dollar, Australian dollar, the Euro, the
British Pound, and certain other European currencies. To the
extent that these estimates are overstated or understated during
periods of currency volatility, we could experience
unanticipated currency gains or losses.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">To reduce exposures associated with nonfunctional
net monetary asset positions in various currencies, we enter
into spot, forward and swap foreign exchange contracts. Our
foreign exchange contracts range from one to three months in
original maturity. In general, we have not hedged anticipated
foreign currency cash flows nor do we enter into forward
contracts for trading purposes. We do not use any derivatives
for speculative purposes. Our existing forward contracts do not
qualify for hedge accounting and accordingly are marked to
market at the end of each reporting period with any unrealized
gain or loss being recognized in the consolidated statement of
operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The unrealized gain (loss) of forward foreign
currency contracts outstanding are presented below as of
December&nbsp;31 (in thousands):
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The carrying value is based on the fair value of
the underlying contracts based on quoted market rates.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Net realized gains and losses arising from
settlement of our forward foreign exchange contracts were not
significant in 2002, 2001, and 2000.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Interest Rate Risk</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In July 2002, we entered into interest rate swap
transactions (the &#147;Transactions&#148;) with two investment
banks (the &#147;Banks&#148;), to hedge the interest rate risk
of its outstanding 5.25%&nbsp;Convertible Subordinated Note due
2006 (the &#147;Notes&#148;) (See note&nbsp;13 to the
consolidated financial statements).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The notional amount of the Transactions was
$345.0&nbsp;million to match the entire principal amount of the
Notes. We will receive from the Banks fixed payments equal to
5.25% percent of the notional amount, payable on
February&nbsp;15 and August&nbsp;15 starting on August&nbsp;15,
2002. In exchange, we will pay to the Banks floating rate
payments based upon the London InterBank Offered Rate
(&#147;LIBOR&#148;) plus 1.66% multiplied by the notional amount
of the Transactions with the LIBOR resetting every three months
beginning August&nbsp;15, 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Transactions will terminate on
August&nbsp;15, 2006 (&#147;Termination Date&#148;), subject to
certain early termination provisions if on or after
August&nbsp;20, 2004 and prior to August&nbsp;15, 2006 the
twenty-day average closing price of our common stock equals or
exceeds $22.59.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Transactions qualified and were designated as
a fair value hedge under SFAS&nbsp;133, <I>&#147;Accounting for
Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&#148;</I> to hedge
against movements in the fair value of the Notes due to changes
in the benchmark interest rate. Under the fair value hedge
model, the derivative is recognized at fair value on the balance
sheet with an offsetting entry to the income statement. In
addition, changes in fair value of the Notes due to changes in
the benchmark interest rate are recognized as a basis adjustment
to the carrying amount of the Notes with an offsetting entry to
the income statement. The gain or loss from the change in fair
value of the Transaction and the offsetting change in the fair
value of the Notes are recognized as interest and other expense.
The net gain recorded as of December&nbsp;31, 2002 was
approximately $1.4&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">To test effectiveness of the hedges, regression
analysis has and will be performed at least quarterly comparing
the change in fair value of the Transactions and the Notes. The
fair values of the Transactions and the Notes are calculated at
least quarterly as the present value of the contractual cash
flows to the expected
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">51
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">maturity date, where the expected maturity date
is based on probability-weighted analysis of interest rates
relating to the five-year LIBOR curve and our stock prices. For
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, the hedge was highly
effective and therefore, the ineffective portion did not have a
material impact on earnings.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In support of our obligation under the
Transactions, we are required to maintain with the Banks a
minimum level of cash and investment collateral of
$20.0&nbsp;million and periodically adjust the overall level of
collateral depending on the fair market value of the
Transactions. This minimum amount of collateral is presented as
restricted cash in our financial statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following table presents the hypothetical
changes in fair values of the interest rate swaps held at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 assuming the following shifts in the
yield curve at December&nbsp;31, 2002. Beginning fair values
represent the fair value of the swaps at December&nbsp;31, 2002
(in millions).
</FONT>

<TR>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">Issuer</FONT></B></TD>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Cash Management Risk</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We maintain balances in cash, cash-equivalents
and investment securities. We maintain our investment securities
in portfolio holdings of various issuers, types and maturities
including money market, government, agency, and corporate bonds.
These securities are classified as available-for-sale, and
consequently are recorded on the balance sheet at fair value
with unrealized gains and losses reported as a separate
component of accumulated other comprehensive income (loss).
These securities are not leveraged and are held for purposes
other than trading.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We also maintain minority investments in private
and publicly traded companies. These investments are reviewed
for other than temporary declines in value on a quarterly basis.
Reasons for other than temporary declines in value include
whether the related company would have insufficient cash flow to
operate for the next twelve months, significant changes in the
operating performance or operating model and changes in market
conditions. As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we held minority
venture investments totaling $2.4&nbsp;million at estimated fair
value. The $2.4&nbsp;million in minority venture investments
included investments in public and private companies, totaling
$2.2&nbsp;million and $200,000, respectively. During 2001, we
recorded a $20.6&nbsp;million impairment charge in connection
with these investments. During 2002, we disposed of our shares
in a majority of these investments. As of December&nbsp;31,
2002, the minority investments we continue to hold totaled
$1.6&nbsp;million at estimated fair value. These investments
were in public companies.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following tables present the hypothetical
changes in fair values in the securities held at
December&nbsp;31, 2002 that are sensitive to the changes in
interest rates. The modeling technique used measures the change
in fair values arising from hypothetical parallel shifts in the
yield curve of plus or minus 50&nbsp;basis points
(&#147;BPS&#148;),
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">52
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">100 BPS and 150 BPS over six and twelve-month
time horizons. Beginning fair values represent the market
principal plus accrued interest and dividends at
December&nbsp;31, 2002. Ending fair values are the market
principal plus accrued interest, dividends and reinvestment
income at six and twelve month time horizons.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following table estimates the fair value of
the portfolio at a six-month time horizon (in millions):
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD colspan="2"></TD>
    <TD></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;7A.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure
    About Market Risk</FONT></I></B></TD>

<FONT size="2">Quantitative and qualitative disclosure about
market risk is set forth at &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion
and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations&#148; under Item&nbsp;7.

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We believe that period-to-period comparisons of
our financial results should not be relied upon as an indication
of future performance.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our revenues and results of operations have been
subject to significant fluctuations, particularly on a quarterly
basis, and our revenues and results of operations could
fluctuate significantly quarter to quarter and year to year.
Causes of such fluctuations may include the volume and timing of
new orders and renewals, the sales cycle for our products, the
introduction of new products, return rates, inventory levels,
product upgrades or updates by us or our competitors, changes in
product mix, changes in product prices and pricing models, the
portion of our licensing fees deferred and recognized as support
and maintenance revenue, seasonality, trends in the computer
industry, general economic conditions (such as the recent
economic slowdown), extraordinary events such as acquisitions or
litigation and the occurrence of unexpected events. For example,
the quarters in 2001 versus the quarters in 2002 benefit from a
greater amount of revenue from multi-element revenue
arrangements deferred from 1998 through 2000 to later periods.
In addition, net income for the quarter ended December&nbsp;31,
2002, reflects a $70.0&nbsp;million charge related to our
pending class action suit which we have agreed to settle,
subject to court approval. Significant quarterly fluctuations in
revenues will cause significant fluctuations in our cash flows
and the cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable and
deferred revenue accounts on our balance sheet. In addition, the
operating results of many software companies reflect seasonal
trends, and our business, financial condition and results of
operations may be affected by such trends in the future. These
trends may include higher net revenue in the fourth quarter as
many customers complete annual budgetary cycles, and lower net
revenue in the summer months when many businesses experience
lower sales, particularly in the European market.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our financial statements and supplementary data
required by this item are set forth at the pages indicated at
Item&nbsp;14(a).
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">54
</FONT>

    <TD><B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;9.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Changes In and Disagreements With
    Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure</FONT></I></B></TD>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Nothing to report.
</FONT>

<!-- link1 "PART III" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="011"></A></DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">PART&nbsp;III</FONT></B>

<!-- link2 "Item 10. Directors and Officers of the Registrant" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="012"></A></DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">Item&nbsp;10.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Directors and Officers of the
    Registrant</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Directors</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We have a classified board of directors which is
divided into three classes with staggered three-year terms. At
each annual meeting, the term of one class expires. Pursuant to
our bylaws, eight directors are authorized for our board of
directors. As of the date of this filing, our board of directors
will consist of seven serving directors with terms expiring in
the years indicated below, and one vacancy.
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="32%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Biographies</FONT></I></B></TD>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Liane Wilson</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
been a director of the company since April 2002. Since March
2001, Ms.&nbsp;Wilson has been self-employed as a consultant.
From June 1999 to March 2001, Ms.&nbsp;Wilson served as vice
chairman of Washington Mutual, Inc. From February 1985 to March
2001, Ms.&nbsp;Wilson held a number of other senior level
positions with Washington Mutual, including executive vice
president for corporate operations and administration and senior
vice president of information systems. During her tenure at
Washington Mutual, she was responsible for corporate technology
and integration activities relating to mergers and acquisitions.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Robert Bucknam</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
been a director of the company since May 2003. Since April 2002,
Mr.&nbsp;Bucknam has served as senior vice president of federal
and international affairs with Cross Match Technologies, Inc., a
fingerprint identification provider. From 1993 to June 2001,
Mr.&nbsp;Bucknam was the chief of staff of the Federal Bureau of
Investigation. Prior to joining the FBI, Mr.&nbsp;Bucknam served
as deputy assistant attorney general with the US Department of
Justice and as deputy chief of the US Attorney&#146;s office in
the Southern District of New&nbsp;York.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Leslie Denend</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
been a director of the company since June 1995. From December
1997 to April 1998, Mr.&nbsp;Denend was president of the
company. From June 1993 to December 1997, Mr.&nbsp;Denend was
chief executive officer and president of Network General
Corporation. From February 1993 to June 1993,
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">56
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Denend was senior vice president of
Network General Corporation. Mr.&nbsp;Denend serves as a
director of Exponent, Inc, Rational Software Corp. and United
Services Automobile Association (USAA).
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">George Samenuk</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
served as our chief executive officer since January 2001 and was
also appointed a director at that time. In April 2001,
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk was named chairman of the board of directors.
From January 2000 to January 2001, Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk served as
president and chief executive officer of TradeOut, Inc., a
private on-line exchange company. From April 1999 to January
2000, Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk served as general manager, Americas at
IBM Corporation. From August 1996 to April 1999,
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk was general manager, ASEAN/ South Asia at IBM
Corporation. From January 2001 to September 2002,
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk served as a director of McAfee.com Corporation,
including serving as the chairman of its board from March 2001
until September 2002, when we purchased the minority interest in
McAfee.com Corporation and merged it into us.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Robert Dutkowsky</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
been a director of the company since April 2001. From January
2002 to July 2003 Mr.&nbsp;Dutkowsky served as president and CEO
of J.D. Edwards&nbsp;&#38; Company, and also served as the
chairman of its board of directors from March 2002 until its
acquisition by PeopleSoft, Inc. in July 2003. From October 2001
to January 2002, Mr.&nbsp;Dutkowsky served as president of the
assembly test division of Teradyne, Inc. From April 2000 to
October 2001, Mr.&nbsp;Dutkowsky served as president and chief
executive officer of GenRad Inc., which was acquired by
Teradyne, Inc. in October 2001. From September 1999 to April
2000, Mr.&nbsp;Dutkowsky served as executive vice president,
Markets and Channels of EMC Corporation. From September 1997 to
September 1999, Mr.&nbsp;Dutkowsky served as president of Data
General, a division of EMC. Prior to joining EMC,
Mr.&nbsp;Dutkowsky spent 20&nbsp;years with IBM Corporation in a
series of sales, marketing and senior management roles.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Denis O&#146;Leary</FONT></I><FONT size="2">
has been a director of the company since July 2003. From May
1993 to February 2003, Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Leary was executive vice
president of J.P.&nbsp;Morgan Chase having joined the bank in
June 1978. During his career at J.P.&nbsp;Morgan
Chase&nbsp;&#38; Co. Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Leary held a number of
senior positions including director of finance, chief
information officer, and head of retail branch banking.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Robert Pangia</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
been a director of the company since April 2001. Since February
2003 Mr.&nbsp;Pangia has been a partner with Ivy Capital
Partners, LLC, a private equity fund. Prior to February 2003
Mr.&nbsp;Pangia was self-employed as a consultant. From April
1987 to December 1996, Mr.&nbsp;Pangia held a number of senior
level management positions at PaineWebber Incorporated,
including director of Investment Banking. Mr.&nbsp;Pangia
currently serves on the board of directors of
ICOS&nbsp;Corporation and IDEC Pharmaceuticals Corporation.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Stephen Richards</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
served as our executive vice president and chief financial
officer since April 2001. In November 2001, Mr.&nbsp;Richards
was also named chief operating officer. From April 1996 to
August 2000, Mr.&nbsp;Richards served in several senior level
executive positions with E*Trade Group, Inc., including chief
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">57
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">financial officer. From October 1984 to March
1996, Mr.&nbsp;Richards served as managing director and chief
financial officer of the Correspondent Clearing Division of Bear
Stearns. He has also held management positions with A.G. Becker
Paribas, Jefferies Group, Inc. and Coopers&nbsp;&#38; Lybrand
LLP. From April 2001 to September 2002 Mr.&nbsp;Richards served
as a director of McAfee.com Corporation until September 2002,
when we purchased the minority interest in McAfee.com
Corporation and merged it into us. Mr.&nbsp;Richards is a
director of TradeStation Group and serves on the Board of
Governors of the Pacific Stock Exchange.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Gene Hodges</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
served as our president since October 2001. Mr.&nbsp;Hodges
served as president of the McAfee product group from January
2000 to October 2001, and from August 1998 to January 2000, he
served as vice president of security marketing. Mr.&nbsp;Hodges
joined Network Associates in 1995 and served in numerous other
management positions with the company. Prior to joining Network
Associates, Mr.&nbsp;Hodges was vice president of Marketing for
a wireless data startup and managed the Office Information
Systems business unit for Digital Equipment Corporation.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Arthur Matin</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
served as president of our McAfee Security group since October
2001. From May 2000 to October 2001, Mr.&nbsp;Matin was senior
vice president of worldwide sales and marketing at CrossWorlds
Software Inc. From January 2000 to May 2000, Mr.&nbsp;Matin
served as senior vice president of worldwide sales for
CrossWorlds. From January 1999 to January 2000, Mr.&nbsp;Matin
served as vice president of the industrial sector at IBM. From
1980 to 1999, Mr.&nbsp;Matin held various other management
positions at IBM, including general manager, Industries, Asia
Pacific, general manager, Product Management, Asia Pacific and
vice president of Sales, Manufacturing Industry.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Kent Roberts</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
served as one of our executive vice president since July 2001
and as general counsel and secretary since January 2001.
Mr.&nbsp;Roberts served as vice president of legal affairs from
February 2000 to July 2001. From May 1998 to February 2000,
Mr.&nbsp;Roberts served as director of legal affairs for the
company. Prior to May 1998 Mr.&nbsp;Roberts practiced law in
Dallas, Texas representing among other clients McAfee
Associates, Inc., the predecessor of Network Associates.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Raymond Smets</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> has
served as president of our Sniffer Technologies group since
October 2002. From January 2001 to October 2002, Mr.&nbsp;Smets
served as vice president of network transformation and a
corporate officer at BellSouth Corporation. From January 1998 to
December 2000 Mr.&nbsp;Smets served as president of BellSouth
Corporation&#146;s Internet business unit BellSouth.net. From
1986 to December 1997 Mr.&nbsp;Smets held various other
management positions at BellSouth Corporation and its
subsidiaries, including severing as president of BellSouth
Applied Technologies.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our officers serve at the discretion of the board
of directors. There are no family relationships among any of our
directors and executive officers.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Compliance with Section&nbsp;16(a) of the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;16(a) of the Securities Exchange Act
of 1934, as amended (the &#147;exchange act&#148;), requires the
company&#146;s officers and directors, and persons who own more
than ten percent of a registered class of the company&#146;s
equity securities, to file certain reports of ownership with the
SEC. Such officers, directors and stockholders are also required
by SEC rules to furnish us with copies of all Section&nbsp;16(a)
forms they file. All reports required to be filed during fiscal
year 2002 pursuant to Section&nbsp;16(a) of the exchange act by
directors, executive officers and 10% beneficial owners were
filed on timely basis, except as follows: Mr.&nbsp;George
Samenuk&#146;s option exercise for 3,000&nbsp;shares in January
2002 was not reported in a timely manner to the SEC,
Mr.&nbsp;Arthur Matin&#146;s option grant of 150,000&nbsp;shares
in October 2002 was not reported to the SEC in a timely manner,
Mr.&nbsp;Stephen Richards sale of 25,000&nbsp;shares in May 2002
was not reported to the SEC in a timely manner and
Ms.&nbsp;Virginia Gemmell&#146;s option exercise and sale of
1,250&nbsp;shares in January 2002 was not reported to the SEC in
a timely manner.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">10b5-1 Trading Plans</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our Insider Trading Policy allows directors,
officers and other employees covered under the policy to
establish, under limited circumstances contemplated by
Rule&nbsp;10b5-1 under the Securities Exchange Act of
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">58
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">1934, written programs that permit automatic
trading of our stock or trading of our stock by an independent
person (such as an investment bank) who is not aware of material
inside information at the time of the trade. As of the filing
date of this report, George Samenuk, our Chairman and Chief
Executive Officer, Stephen C. Richards, our Chief Operating
Officer and Chief Financial Officer, Vernon Gene Hodges, our
President, Kent H. Roberts, our Executive Vice President and
General Counsel, and Arthur Matin, President of our McAfee
Security business, each a Section&nbsp;16 officer, have adopted
Rule&nbsp;10b5-1 trading plans. In addition, Amanda Hodges, the
wife of our President, has also adopted a 10b5-1 trading plan.
We believe that additional directors, officers and employees
have established or may establish such programs. As a result of
our March 2003 announced restatement of certain prior period
financial statements and the delay in the filing of our 2002
Form&nbsp;10-K, all trades in our stock by our Section&nbsp;16
officers, including trades pursuant to Rule&nbsp;10b5-1 trading
plans, were suspended until such time as (i)&nbsp;such report on
Form&nbsp;10-K and restated consolidated financial statements
and (ii)&nbsp;our reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarters
ended March&nbsp;31 and June&nbsp;30, 2003, are each filed with
the SEC. All trades in our common stock made during the fourth
quarter of 2002 and during 2003, prior to such suspension, by
officers who have adopted Rule&nbsp;10b5-1 trading plans were
made pursuant to the terms of such plans.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<!-- link2 "Item 11. Executive Compensation" -->

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Raymond Smets joined us on
October&nbsp;28, 2002 as the president of our Sniffer
Technologies group. In 2002, Mr.&nbsp;Smets received $63,717 in
salary (reflecting an annual base salary of $350,000), $112,500
in bonus (including a $50,000 sign-on bonus) and $81 of group
term life insurance. Mr.&nbsp;Smets also received 250,000
options for shares of our common stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Srivats Sampath served as the chief
executive officer of McAfee.com until September 2002 when we
acquired the minority interest in McAfee.com and merged
McAfee.com into us. In 2002, McAfee.com paid Mr.&nbsp;Sampath
$300,093 in salary, $123,562 in bonus, $350,000 as severance
under his change in control agreement, $4,000 of 401(k)
contributions made by McAfee.com and $405 of group term life
insurance.
</FONT>

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">Except as noted below, all of the above options
    for Network Associates&#146; common stock granted in 2002 vest
    at the rate of one-fourth (or 25%) one year from the date of
    grant and 1/36th&nbsp;per month for the remaining 36&nbsp;months
    of the vesting period. Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s option for
    3,000&nbsp;shares was fully vested upon grant.
    Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s option for 47,000&nbsp;shares will vest
    in full on January&nbsp;15, 2005. Under the 1997 Stock Incentive
    Plan, the board of directors is allowed to modify the terms of
    outstanding options. The exercisability of options may be
    accelerated upon a change in control. Options are cancelled on
    an optionee&#146;s termination of employment under certain
    specified circumstances.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(2)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">Other than options granted with exercise prices
    of $0.01&nbsp;per share, all options were granted at an exercise
    price equal to the fair market value of the common stock on the
    date of grant.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(3)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">These columns present hypothetical future values
    that might be realized on exercise of the options, less the
    exercise price. These values assume that the market price of our
    stock appreciates at a zero, five and ten percent compound
    annual rate over the term of the options. The five and ten
    percent rates of stock price appreciation are presented as
    examples pursuant to the SEC&#146;s proxy rules and do not
    necessarily reflect management&#146;s assessment of our future
    stock price performance. The potential realizable values
    presented are not intended to indicate the value of the options.
    For options granted with an exercise price below the market
    price on the date of grant, the potential realizable values in
    the zero percent appreciation column reflect the difference
    between the option exercise price and the market price on the
    date of grant.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">61
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following table shows stock option exercises
and the value of unexercised stock options held by our chief
executive officer and our four other most highly compensated
executive officers during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002:
</FONT>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">AGGREGATE OPTION EXERCISES IN 2002</FONT></B>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">AND YEAR-END OPTION VALUES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="25%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">1.2&nbsp;million options were issued to
    Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk on January&nbsp;3, 2001 and are immediately
    exercisable. 25% of these shares vested on January&nbsp;3, 2002,
    the first anniversary of Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s employment
    commencement, and the remaining shares vest at a rate
    of &nbsp;1/36th per month for the remaining 36&nbsp;months of
    the vesting period. If Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk exercises these stock
    options with respect to the unvested shares, we have repurchase
    rights with respect to those unvested shares.
    </FONT></TD>

    immediately exercisable. 25% of the shares vested on
    April&nbsp;4, 2002, the first anniversary of
    Mr.&nbsp;Richards&#146; employment commencement and the
    remaining shares vest at a rate of &nbsp;1/36th per month for
    the remaining 36&nbsp;months of the vesting period. If
    Mr.&nbsp;Richards exercises these stock options with respect to
    the unvested shares, we have repurchase rights with respect to
    those unvested shares.

    included above.

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Employment and Change in Control
Arrangements</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">George Samenuk</FONT></I><FONT size="2">
entered into an agreement with us dated January&nbsp;2, 2001
which was amended and restated on October&nbsp;9, 2001, which
provides for his at will employment as our chief executive
officer. This agreement also provides that if Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk
is terminated other than for cause or resigns for good reason,
he will be entitled to the following severance benefits:
(i)&nbsp;twelve months of additional vesting for his initial
stock option grant and restricted stock grant,
(ii)&nbsp;24&nbsp;months of severance payments based on twice
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s base salary and targeted bonus,
(iii)&nbsp;any unpaid amount of Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s sign-on
bonus, and (iv)&nbsp;continued health and other welfare and
fringe benefits through the earlier of (x)&nbsp;18&nbsp;months
from termination or (y)&nbsp;until
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">62
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk is covered by similar plans by a
new employer. If Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk is terminated other than for
cause, or resigns with good reason after (i)&nbsp;the occurrence
of a transaction where our stockholders do not own at least 50%
of the stock of the surviving corporation; (ii)&nbsp;there has
been a change in our directors occurring within a two year
period as a result of which fewer than a majority of our
directors (x)&nbsp;were directors as of the date of the
agreement or (y)&nbsp;were elected, or nominated for election,
to the board by a vote of at least a majority of the incumbent
directors at the time of such election or nomination;
(iii)&nbsp;the acquisition of more than 50% of our stock by
another party or (iv)&nbsp;the sale of substantially all of our
assets, Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk will be entitled to all of the
severance benefits noted above, all of his stock options will
become fully vested and any repurchase rights on his shares of
restricted stock will lapse.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Stephen Richards</FONT></I><FONT size="2">
entered into an agreement with us dated April&nbsp;3, 2001,
which provides for his at will employment as our chief financial
officer. The agreement also provides that if Mr.&nbsp;Richards
is actually or constructively terminated other than for cause he
will be entitled to severance benefits equal to twelve months of
base salary and targeted bonus, plus twelve months of
accelerated vesting on all stock options. If Mr.&nbsp;Richards
is actually or constructively terminated other than for cause,
after (i)&nbsp;the occurrence of a transaction where our
stockholders do not own at least 50% of the stock of the
surviving corporation; (ii)&nbsp;there has been a change in our
directors occurring within a two year period as a result of
which fewer than a majority of our directors (x)&nbsp;were
directors as of the date of the agreement or (y)&nbsp;were
elected, or nominated for election, to the board by a vote of at
least a majority of the incumbent directors at the time of such
election or nomination; (iii)&nbsp;the acquisition of more than
50% of our stock by another party or (iii)&nbsp;the sale of
substantially all of our assets, Mr.&nbsp;Richards will be
entitled to the severance noted above, all of his stock options
will become fully vested, and he will be provided with continued
health care coverage through the earlier of twelve months from
termination or until he is covered by similar plans by a new
employer.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Gene Hodges</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> entered
into an agreement with us dated December&nbsp;3, 2001, which
provides for his at will employment as our president. This
agreement provides that if Mr.&nbsp;Hodges is terminated for any
reason, he shall be entitled to a pro rata targeted bonus if the
relevant goals for the quarter are met, in addition to his
accrued salary and vacation pay. If Mr.&nbsp;Hodges is
terminated other than for cause or resigns for good reason, he
will be entitled to the following severance benefits:
(i)&nbsp;twelve months of severance payments based on
Mr.&nbsp;Hodges&#146; base salary and one-third of his targeted
bonus, (ii)&nbsp;continued health and other welfare and fringe
benefits through the earlier of (x)&nbsp;twelve months from
termination or (y)&nbsp;until Mr.&nbsp;Hodges is covered by
similar plans by a new employer and (iii)&nbsp;all of
Mr.&nbsp;Hodges&#146; shares of restricted stock, if any, and
all stock options will become fully vested and, if applicable,
any repurchase rights on his shares of restricted stock will
lapse. If Mr.&nbsp;Hodges is employed by us upon (i)&nbsp;the
occurrence of a transaction where our stockholders do not own at
least 50% of the stock of the surviving corporation;
(ii)&nbsp;there has been a change in our directors occurring
within a two year period as a result of which fewer than a
majority of our directors (x)&nbsp;were directors as of the date
of the agreement or (y)&nbsp;were elected, or nominated for
election, to the board by a vote of at least a majority of the
incumbent directors at the time of such election or nomination;
(iii)&nbsp;the acquisition of more than 50% of our stock by
another party; or (iv)&nbsp;the sale of substantially all of our
assets, all of Mr.&nbsp;Hodges&#146; shares of restricted stock,
if any, and all stock options held by him will become fully
vested and, if applicable, any repurchase rights on his shares
of restricted stock will lapse. Under this agreement, we will
indemnify Mr.&nbsp;Hodges for any parachute tax payments that
arise pursuant to the agreement.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Arthur Matin</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> entered
into an agreement with us dated October&nbsp;30, 2001, which
provides for his at will employment as the president of our
McAfee product group. This agreement also provides that if
Mr.&nbsp;Matin is terminated other than for cause or resigns for
good reason, he will be entitled to the following severance
benefits: (i)&nbsp;twelve months of additional vesting for stock
options, (ii)&nbsp;twelve months of severance payments based on
Mr.&nbsp;Matin&#146;s base salary and targeted bonus and
(iii)&nbsp;continued health and other welfare and fringe
benefits through the earlier of (x)&nbsp;twelve months from
termination or (y)&nbsp;until Mr.&nbsp;Matin is covered by
similar plans by a new employer. If Mr.&nbsp;Matin is terminated
other than for cause, or resigns with good reason after
(i)&nbsp;the occurrence of a transaction where our stockholders
do not own at least 50% of the stock of the surviving
corporation; (ii)&nbsp;there has been a change in our directors
occurring within a two year period as a result of which fewer
than a majority of our directors (x)&nbsp;were directors as of
the date of the agreement or (y)&nbsp;were elected, or nominated
for election, to the board by a vote of at least a majority of
the incumbent
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">63
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">directors at the time of such election or
nomination; (iii)&nbsp;the acquisition of more than 50% of our
stock by another party or (iv)&nbsp;the sale of substantially
all of our assets, Mr.&nbsp;Matin will be entitled to all of the
severance benefits noted above and all of his stock options will
become fully vested.
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Kent Roberts</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> entered
into an agreement with us dated October&nbsp;9, 2001, which
provides for his at will employment as our executive vice
president and general counsel. This agreement also provides that
if Mr.&nbsp;Roberts is terminated other than for cause or
resigns for good reason, he will be entitled to the following
severance benefits: (i)&nbsp;twelve months of severance payments
based on Mr.&nbsp;Roberts&#146; base salary and one-third of his
targeted bonus, (ii)&nbsp;continued health and other welfare and
fringe benefits through the earlier of (x)&nbsp;twelve months
from termination or (y)&nbsp;until Mr.&nbsp;Roberts is covered
by similar plans by a new employer and (iii)&nbsp;all of
Mr.&nbsp;Roberts&#146; shares of restricted stock, if any, and
all stock options will become fully vested and, if applicable,
any repurchase rights on his shares will lapse. After
(i)&nbsp;the occurrence of a transaction where our stockholders
do not own at least 50% of the stock of the surviving
corporation; (ii)&nbsp;there has been a change in our directors
occurring within a two year period as a result of which fewer
than a majority of our directors (x)&nbsp;were directors as of
the date of the agreement or (y)&nbsp;were elected, or nominated
for election, to the board by a vote of at least a majority of
the incumbent directors at the time of such election or
nomination; (iii)&nbsp;the acquisition of more than 50% of our
stock by another party or (iv)&nbsp;the sale of substantially
all of our assets, all of Mr.&nbsp;Roberts&#146; shares of
restricted stock, if any, and all stock options held by him will
become fully vested and if applicable, any repurchase rights on
his shares will lapses. Under this agreement, we will indemnify
Mr.&nbsp;Roberts for any parachute tax payments that arise
pursuant to the agreement.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Raymond Smets</FONT></I><FONT size="2">
entered into an agreement with us dated October&nbsp;7, 2002,
which provides for his at will employment as the president of
our Sniffer Technologies group. This agreement also provides
that if Mr.&nbsp;Smets is terminated other than for cause or
resigns for good reason, he will be entitled to the following
severance benefits: (i)&nbsp;six months of severance payments
based on Mr.&nbsp;Smets&#146; base salary and one-third of his
targeted bonus, and (ii)&nbsp;continued health and other welfare
and fringe benefits through the earlier of (x)&nbsp;six months
from termination or (y)&nbsp;until Mr.&nbsp;Smets is covered by
similar plans by a new employer. After (i)&nbsp;the occurrence
of a transaction where our stockholders do not own at least 50%
of the stock of the surviving corporation; (ii)&nbsp;there has
been a change in our directors occurring within a two year
period as a result of which fewer than a majority of our
directors (x)&nbsp;were directors as of the date of the
agreement or (y)&nbsp;were elected, or nominated for election,
to the board by a vote of at least a majority of the incumbent
directors at the time of such election or nomination;
(iii)&nbsp;the acquisition of more than 50% of our stock by
another party or (iv)&nbsp;the sale of substantially all of our
assets, all of Mr.&nbsp;Smets&#146; shares of restricted stock,
if any, and all stock options held by him will become fully
vested and if applicable, any repurchase rights on his shares
will lapses. Under this agreement, we will indemnify
Mr.&nbsp;Smets for any parachute tax payments that arise
pursuant to the agreement.
</FONT>
