<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the terms of the Company&#146;s software
license agreements with its customers, the Company agrees that
in the event the software sold infringes upon any patent,
copyright, trademark, or any other proprietary right of a third
party, it will indemnify its customer, licensees, against any
loss, expense, or liability from any damages that may be awarded
against its customer. The Company includes this infringement
indemnification in all of its software license agreements and
selected managed service arrangements. In the event the customer
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">108
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">cannot use the software or service due to
infringement and the Company can not obtain the right to use,
replace or modify the license or service in a commercially
feasible manner so that it no longer infringes then the Company
may terminate the license and provide the customer a pro-rata
refund of the fees paid by the customer for the infringing
license or service. The Company has recorded no liability
associated with this indemnification, as it is not aware of any
pending or threatened infringement actions that are probable
losses.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the terms of certain vendor agreements, in
particular, vendors used as part of the Company&#146;s managed
services, the Company agreed that in the event the service
provided to the customer by the vendor on behalf of the Company
infringes upon any patent, copyright, trademark, or any other
proprietary right of a third party, it will indemnify its
vendor, against any loss, expense, or liability from any damages
that may be awarded against its customer. No maximum liability
is stipulated in these vendor agreements. The Company has
recorded no liability associated with this indemnification, as
it is not aware of any pending or threatened infringement
actions or claims that are probable losses.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the terms of the Company&#146;s agreements
to sell the PGP and Gauntlet assets the Company agreed to
indemnify the purchasers for any breach of representations or
warranties in the agreement as well as for any liabilities
related to the assets prior to sale that are not included in the
purchaser assumed liabilities (undiscovered liabilities). The
maximum potential loss related to the indemnification for breach
of representations or warranties is $2.4&nbsp;million. No
maximum liability is stipulated in the agreement related to any
undiscovered liabilities. To date, the Company has paid
$0.4&nbsp;million under the representations and warranties
indemnification.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has agreed to indemnify members of
the board of directors, as well as officers of the Company, if
they are made a party or are threatened to be made a party to
any proceeding (other than an action by or in the right of the
Company) by reason of the fact that they are an agent of the
Company, or by reason of anything done or not done by them in
any such capacity. The indemnity is for any and all expenses and
liabilities of any type whatsoever (including but not limited
to, judgements, fines and amounts paid in settlement) actually
and reasonably incurred by the directors or officers in
connection with the investigation, defense, settlement or appeal
of such proceeding, provided they acted in good faith. The
Company does maintain insurance coverage for directors and
officers liability (D&#38;O insurance). No maximum liability is
stipulated in these agreements that include indemnifications of
members of the board of directors and officers of the Company.
The Company has recorded no liability associated with these
indemnifications as it is not aware of any pending or threatened
actions or claims against it members of board of directors or
officers that are probable losses in excess of amounts covered
by its D&#38;O insurance.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">If the Company believes a liability associated
with any of the aforementioned indemnifications becomes probable
and the amount of the liability is reasonably estimable or the
maximum amount of a range of loss is reasonably estimable, then
an appropriate liability will be established.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">109
</FONT>

<TR>

    <TD><B><FONT size="2">13.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Convertible Debt</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Convertible debt comprises the following amounts
as of December&nbsp;31 (in thousands):
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="70%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="67%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Zero Coupon Convertible Debentures Due
    2018</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;13, 1998, the Company completed
a private placement of zero coupon convertible subordinated
debentures due in 2018 (the &#147;Debentures&#148;). The
Debentures, with an aggregate face amount at maturity of
$885.5&nbsp;million, generated net proceeds to the Company of
approximately $337.6&nbsp;million. The initial price to the
public for the debentures was $391.06&nbsp;per $1,000 of face
amount at maturity, which equates to a yield to maturity over
the term of the Debentures of 4.75% (on a semi-annual Debentures
equivalent basis).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Debentures are convertible into common stock
at the rate of 8.538&nbsp;shares per $1,000 of face amount at
maturity, which equates to an initial conversion price of
$45.80&nbsp;per share. The Debentures are subordinated in right
of payment to all existing and future Senior Indebtedness (as
defined in the related indenture) and effectively subordinated
in right of payment to all indebtedness and other liabilities of
the Company&#146;s subsidiaries. The Debentures may be redeemed
for cash at the option of the Company beginning on
February&nbsp;13, 2003. At the option of the holder, the Company
will purchase the Debentures on February&nbsp;13, 2003,
February&nbsp;13, 2008 and February&nbsp;13, 2013 at purchase
prices (to be paid in cash or common stock or any combination
thereof, at the election of the Company and subject to certain
conditions) equal to the initial issue price plus the accretion
of the discount on the Debentures to such dates. The Debentures
may also be redeemed at the option of the holder if there is a
Fundamental Change (as defined in the related indenture) at a
price equal to the issue price plus the accretion of the
discount on the debenture to the date of repurchase, subject to
adjustment. The accretion of the discount on the Debentures is
calculated using the effective interest method.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 2002 and 2001, the Company redeemed
Debentures, which had an aggregate face amount at maturity of
$140.0&nbsp;million and $387.0&nbsp;million respectively, at a
net price of $66.2&nbsp;million and $173.7&nbsp;million, which
was financed from the Company&#146;s investment portfolio. In
connection with these repurchases, the Company recognized
extraordinary gains of approximately $26,000 and
$1.7&nbsp;million, net of approximately $17,000 and
$1.2&nbsp;million in taxes in 2002 and 2001, respectively. The
gain was calculated as the difference between the accreted value
of the debt, net of unamortized issuance costs, and the cost of
repurchase.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;18, 2003, outstanding
Debentures, with an aggregate face amount at maturity of
$358.5&nbsp;million, became redeemable for cash at the option of
the holders thereof, at which time the Company repurchased
Debentures which had an aggregate face amount at maturity of
$358.0&nbsp;million for a net price of $177.1&nbsp;million. On
June&nbsp;9, 2003, the Company repurchased the remaining
Debentures with an aggregate face amount at maturity of
$0.5&nbsp;million for a net price of $0.2&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">110
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">5.25%&nbsp;Convertible Subordinated Note
    Due 2006</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;17, 2001, the Company issued
5.25%&nbsp;convertible subordinated notes (&#147;Notes&#148;)
due 2006 with an aggregate principal amount of
$345.0&nbsp;million. The issuance generated net proceeds (after
deducting fees and expenses) of approximately
$335.1&nbsp;million. The amortization of the issuance costs
related to the Notes is calculated using the effective interest
method. The Notes mature on August&nbsp;15, 2006, unless earlier
redeemed by the Company at its option or converted at the
holder&#146;s option. Interest is payable in cash semi-annually
in arrears on February&nbsp;15 and August&nbsp;15 of each year,
commencing February&nbsp;15, 2002. At the option of the holder,
Notes may be converted into the Company&#146;s common stock at
any time, unless previously redeemed, at a conversion price of
$18.07&nbsp;per share. The Notes may also be redeemed at the
option of the holder in the event of a Change of Control (as
defined in the related indenture) for . At any time between
August&nbsp;20, 2004 and August&nbsp;14, 2005, the Company may
redeem all or a portion of the Notes for cash at a repurchase
price of 101.3125% of the principal amount. After
August&nbsp;14, 2005, the repurchase price is 100.0% of the
principal amount. The Notes are unsecured and are subordinated
to all existing and future Senior Indebtedness (as defined in
the related indenture). In July 2002, the Company entered into
an interest rate swap transaction with two investment banks,
which results in the convertible notes being carried at fair
value. (See Note&nbsp;7 to the notes to the Consolidated
Financial Statements).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Aggregate maturities of the value of the
long-term debt outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2002 are as
follows (in thousands):
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;18, 2003, outstanding
    Debentures, with an aggregate face amount at maturity of
    $358.5&nbsp;million, became redeemable for cash at the option of
    the holders thereof, at which time the Company repurchased
    Debentures which had an aggregate face amount at maturity of
    $358.0&nbsp;million for a net price of $177.1. On June&nbsp;9,
    2003, the Company repurchased the remaining Debentures with an
    aggregate face amount at maturity of $0.5&nbsp;million for a net
    price of $0.2&nbsp;million.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(2)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">In 2003, 2004, 2005 and 2006, without giving
    effect to the related floating rate interest rate swap (See
    Note&nbsp;7 to these Notes to Consolidated Financial
    Statements), the Company will make interest payments of
    $18.1&nbsp;million. In the event the Notes are redeemed after
    August&nbsp;20, 2004, the annual interest payments will be
    reduced.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">14.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Employee Benefit Plans</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Company 401(k) and Profit Sharing
    Plan</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s 401(k) and Profit Sharing Plan
cover substantially all Company full-time employees. Under the
Company&#146;s 401(k) and Profit Sharing Plans, the board of
directors, at its discretion, can match employee contributions
in an amount not to exceed 20% of total compensation. Annual
amounts contributed by the Company under the plan are
$4.3&nbsp;million, $4.5&nbsp;million, and $4.2&nbsp;million in
2002, 2001, and 2000, respectively.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Company Employee Stock Purchase
    Plan</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the 1994 Employee Qualified Stock Purchase
Plan (the &#147;1994 Purchase Plan&#148;), the Company may grant
stock purchase rights to all eligible employees during one year
offering periods with exercise dates approximately every six
months (beginning each August and February). The Company has
reserved 3.8&nbsp;million shares of common stock for issuance
under the plan. Shares are purchased through employees&#146;
payroll deductions at exercise prices equal to 85% of the lesser
of the fair value of the Company&#146;s common stock at either
the first day of an offering period or the last day of such
offering period. No participant may purchase more than $25,000
worth of common stock in any one calendar year.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2001, the Company
incurred a shortfall in the number of shares available to meet
the requirements of open purchase periods. Accordingly, the
Company reduced by a pro rata amount the shares available for
purchase by plan participants for the purchase period ending
January&nbsp;31, 2002. After the purchase on January&nbsp;31,
2002, the 1994 Purchase Plan was terminated. In 2002,
approximately 743,000&nbsp;shares were issued under the 1994
Purchase Plan at a weighted average purchase price of $7.24.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In April 2002, the Company&#146;s board of
directors adopted Networks Associates&#146; 2002 Employee Stock
Purchase Plan (the &#147;2002 Purchase Plan&#148;). A total of
2,000,000&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock have
been reserved for issuance under the 2002 Purchase Plan. All
employees are eligible to participate in the 2002 Purchase Plan.
The 2002 Purchase Plan is comprised of two year offering periods
with four six-month purchase periods. Purchase periods occur
twice yearly and each offering effectively contains a 6, 12, 18
and 24-month option. Shares are purchased through Network
Associate employees&#146; contributions at exercise prices equal
to 85% of the lesser of the fair market value of the
Company&#146;s common stock at either the first day of an
offering period or the last day of the purchase period. No
participant may purchase more than $25,000 worth of common stock
in any one calendar year and the maximum number of shares a
participant may purchase during a single offering period is
10,000&nbsp;shares. Under this plan the first purchase will not
occur until 2003.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">McAfee.com Employee Stock Purchase
    Plan</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In September 1999, McAfee.com&#146;s board of
directors adopted McAfee.com&#146;s Employee Stock Purchase Plan
(the &#147;1999 Purchase Plan&#148;). A total of
500,000&nbsp;shares of McAfee.com Class&nbsp;A common stock were
reserved for issuance under the 1999 Purchase Plan, plus annual
increases equal to the lesser of: (a)&nbsp;1.0&nbsp;million
shares; (b)&nbsp;3% of McAfee.com&#146;s outstanding shares on
such date; or (c)&nbsp;an amount determined by McAfee.com&#146;s
board of directors. All McAfee.com full-time employees were
eligible to participate in the 1999 Purchase Plan. The 1999
Purchase Plan was comprised of two-year offering periods with
exercise dates approximately every six months (beginning each
August and February), with the exception of the first offering
period, which commenced on December&nbsp;2, 1999, with the first
exercise date on January&nbsp;31, 2000. Shares were purchased
through McAfee.com employees&#146; payroll deductions at
exercise prices equal to 85% of the lesser of the fair market
value of McAfee.com&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock at either
the first day of an offering period or the last day of such
offering period. No participant could purchase more than $25,000
worth of Class&nbsp;A common stock in any one calendar year and
the maximum number of shares a
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">112
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">participant could purchase during a single
purchase period is 2,500&nbsp;shares. Purchase periods occurred
twice yearly and each offering effectively contained a 6, 12, 18
and 24-month option. On September&nbsp;13, 2002, the Company
acquired the minority interest in McAfee.com and therefore the
McAfee.com employee stock purchase plan was terminated. In 2002,
175,000&nbsp;shares were issued under the 1999 Purchase Plan at
weighted average purchase price of $6.66
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stockholders&#146;
Equity</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Preferred Stock</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has authorized 5.0&nbsp;million
shares of preferred stock, par value $0.01&nbsp;per share. The
Company&#146;s board of directors has authority to provide for
the issuance of the shares of preferred stock in series, to
establish from time to time the number of shares to be included
in each such series and to fix the designation, powers,
preferences and rights of the shares of each such series and the
qualifications, limitations or restrictions thereof, without any
further vote or action by the shareholders.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Company Stock Option Plans</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the amended 1997 Plan, the Company has
reserved 32.5&nbsp;million shares for issuance to employees,
officers, directors, third party contractors and consultants.
The plan provides for an option price no less than 100% of the
fair value of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of
grant for incentive stock options granted to employees and
officers (including directors who are also employees) or 85% of
the fair value on the date of grant for all others. The options
may be exercisable immediately, or over time, but generally
become exercisable 25% one year after commencing employment or
from date of grant and thereafter in monthly increments over
three years. All options under the option plan expire ten years
after grant.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the Stock Option Plan for Outside
Directors, the Company has reserved 1.1&nbsp;million shares of
its common stock for issuance to certain members of its board of
directors who are not employees of the Company or any affiliated
corporation. The plan provides for an option price at fair value
of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant. The
initial grant to each outside director generally vests ratably
over a three-year period. Subsequent option grants will become
exercisable after three years from the date of grant. All
options under the option plan expire ten years after grant.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 1999, the board of directors approved
the 2000 Nonstatutory Stock Option Plan. Under the plan, as
amended in January 2001, the Company has reserved
11.5&nbsp;million shares of its common stock for issuance to
employees, officers, directors, third party contracts and
consultants. The plan provides for an option price at fair value
of the Company&#146;s common stock on the date of grant. The
options become exercisable over a period of four years: 25%
become exercisable one year from the date of grant and the
remaining become exercisable ratably in monthly increments over
three years. All options under the option plan expire ten years
after grant.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">113
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2002, approximately
10.0&nbsp;million options to purchase common stock of the
Company were exercisable at an average exercise price of $14.27.
For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, net proceeds from
exercise of stock options amounted to $97.6&nbsp;million, which
is net of a reduction in stock option exercise proceeds of
$7.9&nbsp;million. This reduction is for the payment of the
Company&#146;s cash obligation, not exceeding the full exercise
price, which is triggered upon exercise of the Company stock
options that were granted in exchange for the McAfee options
(see Note&nbsp;21 to the notes to these consolidated financial
statements).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2001, approximately
10.9&nbsp;million options to purchase common stock of the
Company were exercisable at an average exercise price of $20.01.
During 2001, the Company used approximately 3.2&nbsp;million
shares of treasury stock to fulfill employee option exercises
and shares issued under the employee stock purchase plan.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2000, approximately
9.2&nbsp;million outstanding options to purchase common stock of
the Company were exercisable at an average exercise price of
$17.93. During 2000, the Company used approximately
3.0&nbsp;million shares of treasury stock to fulfill employee
option exercises and shares issued under the employee stock
purchase plan.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">114
</FONT>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">McAfee.com Stock Option Plans</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In January 1999, the McAfee.com&#146;s board of
directors approved the 1999 Stock Plan (the &#147;McAfee
Plan&#148;), as amended June&nbsp;19, 1999. Under the McAfee
Plan, McAfee.com reserved 10.9&nbsp;million shares of its
Class&nbsp;A common stock for issuance to employees, officers,
directors and consultants. The McAfee Plan also provided for
automatic annual increases to be added at the annual
stockholder&#146;s meeting, equal to the lower of:
(a)&nbsp;2.5&nbsp;million shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock,
(b)&nbsp;5% of the outstanding shares of all Class&nbsp;A common
stock on that date, or (c)&nbsp;an amount determined by the
McAfee.com&#146;s board of directors. The McAfee Plan provided
for an option price no less than 100% of the fair market value
of McAfee.com&#146;s common stock on the date of grant for
incentive stock options granted to employees and officers
(including directors who are also employees) or 85% of the fair
market value on the date of grant for all others. The options
were exercisable immediately, or became exercisable over time,
generally 25% one year after commencing employment or from date
of grants and thereafter in monthly increments over three years.
All options under the McAfee Plan expired ten years after grant.
Unvested options on termination of employment were canceled and
returned to the McAfee Plan.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In September 1999, McAfee.com adopted the 1999
Director Option Plan. McAfee.com had reserved
150,000&nbsp;shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock for
issuance under the plan to certain members of its board of
directors who were not employees of McAfee.com or any affiliated
corporation. Under this plan the number of shares reserved
automatically increased at the date of the McAfee.com Annual
Stockholder&#146;s Meeting by the number of shares required to
restore the reserve available for new options to
150,000&nbsp;shares. Each outside director was automatically
granted an option to purchase 40,000&nbsp;shares of
McAfee.com&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock on the date at which
they become a director. Each anniversary thereafter, each
outside director was automatically granted an option to purchase
10,000&nbsp;shares of McAfee.com&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common
stock. Both the initial and subsequent grants became exercisable
at a rate of 25% after one year and 1/48 each month thereafter.
All options under grant expire ten years after grant. Unvested
options on termination of employment were canceled and returned
to the Director Option Plan.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">115
</FONT>

<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In September 2002, the Company acquired the
minority interest in McAfee.com. At that time, all outstanding
options were converted and transferred into the Company&#146;s
option plans and the McAfee.com stock option plans were
terminated. The following is the aggregate activity under the
McAfee.com stock option plans through the date of acquisition
(in thousands, except per share data):
</FONT>

and McAfee.com has been calculated using the Black-Scholes
option-pricing model using the multiple option approach. A
typical option grant vests over a four-year period. Parameters
for the option analysis are listed below.

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average grant date fair value of
options granted by the Company in 2002, 2001 and 2000 was
$10.07, $4.86 and $16.07, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average fair value of restricted
stock granted by the Company in 2002 and 2001 was $27.19 and
$7.67, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">No options were granted to employees below or
above fair value during 2001 and 2000. During 2002, the Company
exchanged approximately 2.3&nbsp;million options in the
McAfee.com acquisition at exercise prices below fair value as of
the acquisition date (see Note&nbsp;21 to the Notes to these
Consolidated Financial Statements).
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average grant date fair value of
options granted by McAfee.com to employees in 2002, 2001 and
2000 were $7.76, $8.44 and $17.54, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company and McAfee.com have also estimated
the fair value of purchase rights issued under their employee
stock purchase plans. Rights under these plans were also valued
using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. Parameters for the
purchase rights analysis are listed below:
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

    <TD width="3%"></TD>

    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <I><FONT size="2">The Company:</FONT></I></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="80%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="65%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Stock Repurchase Plan and Put
    Options</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In May 1999, the board of directors authorized
the Company to repurchase up to $100&nbsp;million of its common
stock in the open market. In July 2000, the board of directors
authorized the Company to repurchase additional common stock of
up to $50.0&nbsp;million in the open market. Through
December&nbsp;31, 2001, the Company repurchased 5.0&nbsp;million
shares of its common stock bringing total cash outlay to date to
approximately $112.9&nbsp;million. The timing and size of any
future stock repurchases are subject to market conditions, stock
prices, the Company&#146;s cash position and other cash
requirements. Such repurchases are intended to cover the
Company&#146;s reissuances under the Employee Stock Purchase
Plan (ESPP), the 1997 Plan, and issuances related to potential
mergers and acquisitions.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">118
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On August&nbsp;2, 1999, February&nbsp;16, 2000
and May&nbsp;31, 2000, the Company sold &#147;European
style&#148; put options for 3&nbsp;million shares of the
Company&#146;s common stock as part of its stock repurchase
plan. On August&nbsp;3, 2000, put options sold on August&nbsp;2,
1999 for 1.0&nbsp;million shares were exercised in the
Company&#146;s stock. In February 2001, the Company settled the
remaining put options, which resulted in the purchase of
2.0&nbsp;million shares of the Company&#146;s stock for
approximately $53.8&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Preferred Shares Rights
    Agreement</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;19, 1998, pursuant to a Preferred
Shares Rights Agreement between the Company and BankBoston, N.A.
as Rights Agent, the Board of Directors of the Company announced
that it had declared a dividend distribution of one preferred
share purchase right (a &#147;Right&#148;) on each outstanding
share of the Company&#146;s common stock. Each Right will
entitle stockholders to buy one one-thousandth of a share of the
Company&#146;s Series&nbsp;B Participating Preferred Stock at an
exercise price of $200.00. The Rights will become exercisable
following the tenth day after a person or group announces the
acquisition of 15% or more of the Company&#146;s common stock or
announces commencement of a tender or exchange offer, the
consummation of which would result in ownership by the person or
group of 15% or more of the common stock of the Company. The
Company will be entitled to redeem the Rights at $0.01&nbsp;per
Right at any time on or before the tenth day following
acquisition by a person or group of 15% or more of the
Company&#146;s common stock. The dividend distribution was made
on November&nbsp;3, 1998, payable to the stockholders of record
on November&nbsp;3, 1998. The Rights will expire on
October&nbsp;20, 2008.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Significant components of net deferred tax assets
are as follows (in thousands):
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="80%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="69%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="7%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="7%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="7"></TD>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company has net
operating loss carryovers for federal income tax purposes of
approximately $120.8&nbsp;million. These net operating loss
carryovers have expiration dates ranging from 2009 to 2017. The
decrease in the valuation allowance primarily relates to changes
in our assessment of the realizability of certain foreign tax
credit carryovers and net loss carry forwards relating to the
Company&#146;s former subsidiary, McAfee.com.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">U.S.&nbsp;income taxes were not provided for on a
cumulative total of approximately $82.7&nbsp;million of retained
earnings of certain non-U.S.&nbsp;subsidiaries. The Company
intends to reinvest these earnings indefinitely in operations
outside the United States.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">121
</FONT>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="90%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="49%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">18.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Business
Segment and Major Customer Information</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has concluded that it has one
business and operates in one industry, developing, marketing,
distributing and supporting computer security solutions for
large enterprises, governments, small and medium sized business
and consumer users, as well as resellers and distributors
Management measures profitability based on the Company&#146;s
five geographic regions: North America, EMEA, Japan,
Asia-Pacific (excluding
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">123
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">Japan) and Latin America. The regions are
evidence of the operating structure of the Company&#146;s
internal organization.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company markets and sells, through its
geographic regions, anti-virus and security software, hardware
and services; network management software, hardware and
services; and help desk software and services. These products
and services are marketed and sold worldwide directly to
consumers, corporate and government users, as well as through
resellers, distributors, systems integrators and retailers. In
addition, the Company offers web sites, which provide suites of
on-line products and services personalized for the user based on
the users&#146; PC configuration, attached peripherals and
resident software. The Company also offers managed security and
availability applications to corporations and governments on the
Internet.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Following is the summary of the Company&#146;s
revenue and income (loss) from operations by geographic region.
The accounting policies of the businesses and geographic
segments are the same as disclosed in Note&nbsp;2 to these Notes
to Consolidated Financial Statements. To reconcile to the
consolidated financial statements, where applicable,
&#147;Corporate&#148; represents costs and expenses associated
with corporate activities. Corporate activities include general
and administrative expenses and corporate marketing expenses of
$37.3&nbsp;million, $48.6&nbsp;million and $52.0&nbsp;million in
2002, 2001 and 2000, respectively; stock-based compensation
charges; and acquisition, restructuring and other related costs.
These corporate expenses are not considered attributable to any
specific geographic region. Summarized financial information
concerning the Company&#146;s net revenue and operating income
(losses) by business and geographic region is as follows (in
thousands):
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Following is a summary of the Company&#146;s
long-lived assets and total assets by business and by geographic
region. Long-lived assets are capital expenditures, including
land purchases. Assets purchased to support Infrastructure
general and administrative activities, including land purchases,
are included in &#147;Corporate&#148; in the &#147;Long-lived
assets&#148; table below. Assets purchased to support
Infrastructure general and administrative activities, including
land purchases, are included in &#147;Corporate&#148; in the
&#147;Total assets&#148; table, below. These corporate assets
are not assigned to any specific geographic region. Summarized
financial information
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has amended the previously disclosed
analysis of net product revenue information for the software
licenses, hardware and retail categories to reflect a refinement
in its methodology of allocating the Company&#146;s revenue
related reserves to the individual categories shown above. For
the purposes of calculating the previously disclosed
information, reserves had been allocated to the individual line
items in the above analysis based on a pro-rata allocation using
gross revenue for each line item during the quarter. The amended
analysis reflects a methodology that specifically applies
certain revenue-related reserves to the applicable product
revenue line items. The remaining revenue related reserves
continue to be allocated to each of these
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">125
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">line items using a pro-rata allocation. This
reallocation has not been performed for 2000, as it is
impracticable to do so and accordingly 2000 has not been
presented.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001, one customer
had an accounts receivable balance greater than 10% of the
Company&#146;s total accounts receivable balance. During 2002,
2001 and 2000, one customer accounted for 25%, 24% and 27%,
respectively, of the total net revenue for each year. During
2002, another customer accounted for 10% of the net revenue, but
accounted for less than 10% for 2001 and 2000. The revenue
derived from these customers is reported mainly in North America
and Europe segments.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">19.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Litigation</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">General</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">From time to time, the Company has been subject
to litigation including the pending litigation described below.
The Company&#146;s current estimated range of liability related
to some of the pending litigation below is based on claims for
which management can estimate the amount and range of loss. The
Company has recorded the minimum estimated liability related to
those claims, where there is a range of loss. Because of the
uncertainties related to both the amount and range of loss on
the remaining pending litigation, management is unable to make a
reasonable estimate of the liability that could result from an
unfavorable outcome. As additional information becomes
available, the Company will assess its potential liability and
revise its estimates. Pending or future litigation could be
costly, could cause the diversion of management&#146;s attention
and could upon resolution, have a material adverse effect on the
business, results of operations, financial condition and cash
flow.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In addition, the Company is engaged in certain
legal and administrative proceedings incidental to our normal
business activities and believes that these matters will not
have a material adverse effect on our financial position,
results of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Securities Cases</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Between December&nbsp;29, 2000 and
February&nbsp;7, 2001, the Company and certain of its current
and former officers and directors were named in securities class
action lawsuits filed in the United States District Court for
the Northern District of California. On September&nbsp;24, 2001,
a consolidated class action complaint, styled <I>In re Network
Associates, Inc.&nbsp;II Securities Litigation,</I> was filed
which asserts claims against the Company, William Larson,
Prabhat Goyal and Peter Watkins on behalf of a putative class of
persons who purchased the Company&#146;s stock between
July&nbsp;19 and December&nbsp;26, 2000. The complaint asserts
causes of action (and seeks unspecified damages) for alleged
violations of Exchange Act Section&nbsp;10(b)/ SEC
Rule&nbsp;10b-5 and Exchange Act Section&nbsp;20(a). In
particular, the complaint alleges that defendants engaged in
improper practices designed to increase the Company&#146;s
revenues and earnings and that, as a result of those practices,
the Company&#146;s class period financial statements were false
and misleading and failed to comply with Generally Accepted
Accounting Principles (GAAP). After a hearing on
defendants&#146; motion to dismiss was held on April&nbsp;16,
2002, the Court entered an order approving a jointly stipulated
withdrawal of defendants&#146; motion to dismiss. On
September&nbsp;30, 2002, plaintiffs filed a first amended and
consolidated complaint. The amended and consolidated complaint
asserts claims on behalf of an expanded class of plaintiffs,
<I>i.e.</I>, persons who purchased the Company&#146;s stock
between April&nbsp;15, 1999 and December&nbsp;26, 2000, and, in
addition to reasserting the allegations contained in the
consolidated complaints, adds allegations regarding the
Company&#146;s restatement of its 1998, 1999, and 2000 financial
statements, which restatement resulted from the Company&#146;s
discovery of certain accounting inaccuracies impacting those
financial statements. The FAC also adds Terry Davis, the
Company&#146;s former Controller as a party defendant. On
November&nbsp;11, 2002, the Company and the individual
defendants each moved to dismiss certain claims asserted on the
first amended and consolidated complaint. Prior to the hearing
on Defendant&#146;s motions, which took place on
February&nbsp;11, 2003, plaintiff voluntarily dismissed Peter
Watkins as a party defendant in the lawsuit. A decision on the
remaining motions to dismiss
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">126
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">was issued on March&nbsp;25, 2003, where the
Court granted, in part, defendants&#146; motion to dismiss. On
September&nbsp;23, 2003, the Company and the plaintiffs entered
into a memorandum of agreement of settlement settling the matter
for $70.0&nbsp;million. The settlement was preliminarily
approved by the court on October&nbsp;22, 2003 and is subject to
notice to and opportunity to object and opt-out by members of
the Class and approval by the court following a hearing on any
objections to the settlement.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;5, 2001, the Company was
nominally sued in a derivative lawsuit filed in the Superior
Court in Santa&nbsp;Clara County. The lawsuit, captioned <I>Mead
Ann Krim&nbsp;v. William L. Larson, et&nbsp;al.</I>, Case
No.&nbsp;CV795734, asserts claims against William Larson, Peter
Watkins, Prabhat Goyal, Leslie Denend, Virginia Gemmell, Edwin
Harper, Enzo Torresi (collectively the &#147;individual
defendants&#148;), and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP for breach of
fiduciary duty, unjust enrichment and professional negligence
against the accountants. In particular, the complaint alleges
that the defendants engaged in a course of conduct by which they
improperly accounted for revenue from software license sales,
and that, as a result of their actions, certain of the
Company&#146;s financial statements were false and misleading
and not in compliance with GAAP. The complaint seeks an
unspecified amount of damages. Nominal defendant Network
Associates, Inc. filed a demurrer to the complaint on
May&nbsp;21, 2001. A hearing on the demurrer was held on
June&nbsp;29, 2001. On July&nbsp;24, 2001, the Court sustained
the demurrer with leave to amend. By Order dated August&nbsp;21,
2001, the Court granted plaintiff limited discovery for purposes
of amending the complaint to meet the demand futility test
imposed by Delaware law. Plaintiff filed an amended complaint on
December&nbsp;26, 2001. Nominal defendant Network Associates,
Inc. filed a demurrer, which was joined by the individual
defendants, to the amended complaint on January&nbsp;30, 2002. A
hearing on the demurrer was held on March&nbsp;8, 2002. The
Court entered an order on March&nbsp;28, 2002 sustaining the
demurrer without leave to amend and dismissing the amended
complaint with prejudice. Plaintiff filed a Notice of Appeal in
the California Court of Appeals, Sixth Appellate District on
June&nbsp;24, 2002. On December&nbsp;19, 2002, plaintiff filed a
motion seeking the Court&#146;s approval of the parties&#146;
settlement stipulation and dismissal of the case with prejudice.
By order dated January&nbsp;7, 2003, the Court entered the
parties&#146; stipulation and dismissed the case with prejudice
as to all parties and all claims.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In March 2002, several putative securities class
action lawsuits were filed in the Court of Chancery in the State
of Delaware, County of New Castle, and the Superior Court of the
State of California, County of Santa&nbsp;Clara, arising out of
the Company&#146;s proposed acquisition of McAfee.com
Corporation (&#147;McAfee.com&#148;). The lawsuits named as
defendants Network Associates and certain of McAfee.com&#146;s
officers and directors, and with respect to the Delaware Court
of Chancery actions, McAfee.com. The lawsuit filed in
Santa&nbsp;Clara County is encaptioned <I>Peyton&nbsp;v.
Richards, et&nbsp;al.</I>, No.&nbsp;CV 806199. The lawsuits
filed in the Delaware Court of Chancery, which were encaptioned
<I>Bank&nbsp;v. McAfee.com Corp., et&nbsp;al.</I>, Civil Action
No.&nbsp;19481; <I>Birnbaum&nbsp;v. Sampath, et&nbsp;al.</I>,
Civil Action No.&nbsp;19482 NC; <I>Brown&nbsp;v. Sampath,
et&nbsp;al.</I>, Civil Action No.&nbsp;19483 NC; <I>Chin&nbsp;v.
McAfee.com Corp., et&nbsp;al.,</I> Civil Action No.&nbsp;19484
NC; <I>Monastero&nbsp;v. Sampath, et&nbsp;al.</I>, Civil Action
No.&nbsp;19485; and <I>Ebner&nbsp;v. Sampath, et&nbsp;al.</I>,
Civil Action No.&nbsp;19487, were consolidated into a single
case (the &#147;Consolidated Action&#148;) by Court order dated
April&nbsp;9, 2002. Plaintiffs amended the complaint in the
Consolidated Action on July&nbsp;8, 2002. The second amended
complaint asserts claims against defendants for breach of
fiduciary duty on the grounds that (i)&nbsp;the price at which
Network Associates proposed to consummate the current exchange
offer purportedly was unfair and inadequate, and
(ii)&nbsp;defendants purportedly failed to disclose information
material to assessing the propriety of the exchange offer. The
plaintiffs seek, among other things, to recover unspecified
damages and costs and to enjoin or rescind the transaction
contemplated by the offer. On September&nbsp;19, 2002 the
parties entered into a memorandum of understanding. On
July&nbsp;18, 2003, the Delaware Court of Chancery approved the
settlement and the case was dismissed. Another class action
lawsuit was filed on April&nbsp;9, 2002 in the United States
District Court for the Northern District of California,
encaptioned <I>Getty&nbsp;v. Sampath, et. al.</I>, Case
No.&nbsp;C 02 1692. On September&nbsp;30, 2002, the parties in
the <I>Getty</I> action filed a joint request with United States
District Court for the entry of an order staying the
<I>Getty</I> proceedings until after the Delaware Chancery Court
has an opportunity to approve the
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">127
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NETWORKS ASSOCIATES, INC. AND
SUBSIDIARIES</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL
STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151; (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">proposed settlement in the Delaware Consolidated
Action. On April&nbsp;2, 2002, defendants removed the California
state action encaptioned <I>Peyton&nbsp;v. Richards,
et&nbsp;al.</I>, No.&nbsp;CV 806199 to the United States
District Court for the Northern District of California.
Subsequently, by stipulation filed June&nbsp;20, 2002, the
parties in <I>Peyton</I> agreed for the action to be remanded to
California Superior Court for the County of Santa&nbsp;Clara
solely for the purpose of allowing plaintiff Justin Peyton to
dismiss the action. On July&nbsp;1, 2002, a putative class
action lawsuit encaptioned <I>Peyton&nbsp;v. Richards, et
al</I>., Case No.&nbsp;CV 809111, was filed in the California
Superior Court for the County of Santa&nbsp;Clara against
Network Associates and various officers and directors of
McAfee.com. The complaint generally alleges that (i)&nbsp;the
defendant directors of McAfee.com are liable for breach of
fiduciary duty because they failed to maximize the price of
Network Associates&#146; exchange offer, and (ii)&nbsp;defendant
Network Associates aided and abetted these breaches of fiduciary
duty by structuring the exchange offer in terms preferential to
Network Associates. The plaintiff seeks, among other things, to
enjoin or rescind the transaction contemplated by the offer, to
recover costs, and to impose a constructive trust upon any
benefits improperly received by defendants. On
September&nbsp;20, 2002, the Superior Court entered an order
approving the parties&#146; joint stipulation to stay the
<I>Peyton</I> proceedings pending the Delaware Chancery
Court&#146;s approval of the proposed settlement in the Del
aware Consolidated Action. On August&nbsp;14, 2003, the parties
entered into a stipulation for an order that would dismiss the
<I>Peyton</I> action with prejudice.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Certain investment bank underwriters, the
Company, and certain of our directors and officers have been
named in a putative class action for violation of the federal
securities laws in the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New&nbsp;York, captioned <I>In re
McAfee.com Corp. Initial Public Offering Securities
Litigation,</I> 01 Civ.&nbsp;7034 (SAS). This is one of a number
of cases challenging underwriting practices in the initial
public offerings (&#147;IPOs&#148;) of more than 300 companies.
These cases have been coordinated for pretrial proceedings as
<I>In re Initial Public Offering Securities Litigation,</I> 21
MC 92 (SAS). Plaintiffs generally allege that certain
underwriters engaged in undisclosed and improper underwriting
activities, namely the receipt of excessive brokerage
commissions and customer agreements regarding post-offering
purchases of stock in exchange for allocations of IPO shares.
Plaintiffs also allege that various investment bank securities
analysts issued false and misleading analyst reports. The
complaint against the Company claims that the purported improper
underwriting activities were not disclosed in the registration
statements for McAfee.Com&#146;s IPO and seeks unspecified
damages on behalf of a purported class of persons who purchased
the Company&#146;s securities or sold put options during the
time period from December&nbsp;1, 1999 to December&nbsp;6, 2000.
On February&nbsp;19, 2003 the Court issued an Opinion and Order
dismissing certain of the claims against the Company with leave
to amend. A settlement proposal was accepted by the Company on
July&nbsp;15, 2003 and is awaiting Court approval.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Other Matters</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On February&nbsp;6, 2002, the Attorney General of
the State of New&nbsp;York filed a Petition in the Supreme
Court, New&nbsp;York County, alleging that certain restrictions
posted by the Company on and with its software are deceptive,
unenforceable and illegal. The challenged restrictions relate to
publication of benchmark tests and reviews concerning the
Company&#146;s software products. The Petition seeks damages,
costs and an injunction requiring the Company to give notice to
the Attorney General before making any representations to
consumers concerning &#147;the right to review, test or
criticize&#148; its products. This is a &#147;special
proceeding&#148; under New&nbsp;York law. The Company filed
papers in opposition to the Petition in which it denied the
substantive allegations of the Petition and asserted various
affirmative defenses. By a Final Order of the Supreme Court,
New&nbsp;York County dated May&nbsp;6, 2003, the Company and the
Attorney General of the State of New&nbsp;York resolved the
action.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On March&nbsp;22, 2002, the Securities and
Exchange Commission notified the Company that it has commenced a
&#147;Formal Order of Private Investigation&#148; into the
Company&#146;s accounting practices. The SEC investigation is
continuing, and the Company continues to provide documents and
information to the SEC.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">128
</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

    <TD width="95%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">20.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Related Party Transactions</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the terms of the amended and restated
employment agreement for Mr.&nbsp;George Samenuk, Chairman of
the Board and Chief Executive Officer, the Company agreed to
loan Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk the funds necessary to pay the taxes due
on each vesting date for the 400,000&nbsp;shares of restricted
stock granted to Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk on January&nbsp;3, 2001. In
addition, the Company agreed to loan Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk the funds
necessary to pay the taxes due on the 3,000&nbsp;shares of stock
granted to Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk on January&nbsp;15, 2002. In
accordance with the provisions of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of
2002, no additional loans were made to Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk after
July&nbsp;30, 2002 and no material modifications were made to
any loan outstanding on that date. In total the Company extended
5&nbsp;separate loans to Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2002, 4&nbsp;loans in an aggregate amount of
approximately $955,000 were outstanding. The loans each had a
two-year maturity and bore interest at the applicable federal
rate. The loans were full recourse and secured by
Mr.&nbsp;Samenuk&#146;s restricted stock and 3,000&nbsp;shares
of stock. The last remaining loan was fully repaid in October
2003.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">21.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Stock-Based Compensation</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company expensed $22.4&nbsp;million,
$24.9&nbsp;million and $10.1&nbsp;million in 2002, 2001 and
2000, respectively. Stock-based compensation charges relate
primarily to the exchange of McAfee.com options in connection
with the company&#146;s acquisition of the publicly traded
minority interest in McAfee.com, non-recurring stock
compensation charges primarily related to executive compensation
and the repricing of employee stock options. The Company does
expect significant future stock-based compensation charges
related to the exchange of McAfee.com options and repriced
employee stock options.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s stock based compensation
charges are made up of the following for the years presented (in
thousands):
</FONT>
